#Text=CHAPTER XIV .
#Text=WESSEX GETS BUSY
#Text=Innes rose from the chair usually occupied by Paul Harley as Detective Inspector Wessex , with a very blank face , walked into the office .
#Text=Innes looked haggard and exhibited unmistakable signs of anxiety .
#Text=Since he had received that dramatic telephone message from his chief he had not spared himself for a moment .

#Text=The official machinery of Scotland Yard was at work endeavouring to trace the missing man , but since it had proved impossible to find out from where the message had been sent , the investigation was handicapped at the very outset .
#Text=Close inquiries at the Savoy Hotel had shown that Harley had not been there .

#Text=Wessex , who was a thorough artist within his limitations , had satisfied himself that none of the callers who had asked for Ormuz Khan , and no one who had loitered about the lobbies , could possibly have been even a disguised Paul Harley .
#Text=To Inspector Wessex the lines along which Paul Harley was operating remained a matter of profound amazement and mystification .
#Text=His interview with Mr. Nicol Brinn had only served to baffle him more hopelessly than ever .

#Text=The nature of Paul Harley ’s inquiries -- inquiries which , presumably from the death of Sir Charles Abingdon , had led him to investigate the movements of two persons of international repute , neither apparently having even the most remote connection with anything crooked -- was a conundrum for the answer to which the detective inspector sought in vain .
#Text=“ I can see you have no news , ” said Innes , dully .
#Text=“ To be perfectly honest , ” replied Wessex , “ I feel like a man who is walking in his sleep .
#Text=Except for the extraordinary words uttered by the late Sir Charles Abingdon , I fail to see that there is any possible connection between his death and Mr. Nicol Brinn .
#Text=I simply ca n’t fathom what Mr. Harley was working upon .
#Text=To my mind there is not the slightest evidence of foul play in the case .
#Text=There is no motive ; apart from which , there is absolutely no link . ”

#Text=“ Nevertheless , ” replied Innes , slowly , “ you know the chief , and therefore you know as well as I do that he would not have instructed me to communicate with you unless he had definite evidence in his possession .
#Text=It is perfectly clear that he was interrupted in the act of telephoning .
#Text=He was literally dragged away from the instrument . ”
#Text=“ I agree , ” said Wessex .
#Text=“ He had got into a tight corner somewhere right enough .
#Text=But where does Nicol Brinn come in ? ”
#Text=“ How did he receive your communication ? ”
#Text=“ Oh , it took him fairly between the eyes .
#Text=There is no denying that .
#Text=He knows something . ”
#Text=“ What he knows , ” said Innes , slowly , “ is what Mr. Harley learned last night , and what he fears is what has actually befallen the chief . ”
#Text=Detective Inspector Wessex stood beside the Burmese cabinet , restlessly drumming his fingers upon its lacquered surface .
#Text=“ I am grateful for one thing , ” he said .
#Text=“ The press has not got hold of this story . ”
#Text=“ They need never get hold of it if you are moderately careful . ”
#Text=“ For several reasons I am going to be more than moderately careful .
#Text=Whatever Fire-Tongue may be , its other name is sudden death ! It ’s a devil of a business ; a perfect nightmare . But -- ” he paused --
#Text=“ I am wondering what on earth induced Mr. Harley to send that parcel of linen to the analyst . ”
#Text=“ The result of the analysis may prove that the chief was not engaged upon any wild-goose chase . ”
#Text=“ By heavens ! ”
#Text=Wessex sprang up , his eyes brightened , and he reached for his hat , “ that gives me an idea ! ”
#Text=“ The message with the parcel was written upon paper bearing the letterhead of the late Sir Charles Abingdon .
#Text=So Mr. Harley evidently made his first call there ! I ’m off , sir !
#Text=The trail starts from that house ! ”
#Text=Leaving Innes seated at the big table with an expression of despair upon his face , Detective Inspector Wessex set out .
#Text=He blamed himself for wasting time upon the obvious , for concentrating too closely upon the clue given by Harley ’s last words to Innes before leaving the office in Chancery Lane .
#Text=It was poor workmanship .
#Text=He had hoped to take a short cut , and it had proved , as usual , to be a long one .
#Text=Now , as he sat in a laggard cab feeling that every minute wasted might be a matter of life and death , he suddenly became conscious of personal anxiety .
#Text=He was a courageous , indeed a fearless , man , and he was subconsciously surprised to find himself repeating the words of Nicol Brinn :
#Text=“ Be careful -- be very careful ! ”
#Text=With all the ardour of the professional , he longed to find a clue which should lead him to the heart of the mystery .

#Text=Innes had frankly outlined the whole of Paul Harley ’s case to date , and Detective Inspector Wessex , although he had not admitted the fact , had nevertheless recognized that from start to finish the thing did not offer one single line of inquiry which he would have been capable of following up .
#Text=That Paul Harley had found material to work upon , had somehow picked up a definite clue from this cloudy maze , earned the envious admiration of the Scotland Yard man .

#Text=Arrived at his destination , he asked to see Miss Abingdon , and was shown by the butler into a charmingly furnished little sitting room which was deeply impressed with the personality of its dainty owner .
#Text=It was essentially and delightfully feminine .
#Text=Yet in the decorations and in the arrangement of the furniture there was a note of independence which was almost a note of defiance .
#Text=Phyllis Abingdon , an appealingly pathetic figure in her black dress , rose to greet the inspector .
